contentrichtext.text: '''Xu Liangying''' ([[traditional Chinese]]: 許良英, [[simplified Chinese]]: 许良英), (3 May 1920 - 28 January 2013) was a [[Chinese people|Chinese]] [[physicist]], [[translator]] and a [[historian]] and [[philosopher]] of [[natural science]] in [[People's Republic of China|China]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rue89.com/2013/01/28/mort-de-xu-liangying-92-ans-savant-chinois-et-dissident-toute-sa-vie-239060 |title=Mort de Xu Liangying, 92 ans, savant chinois et dissident toute sa vie | Une Vigie Rue89 |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Rue89.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-28}}</ref> ==Biography== Xu was born in [[Linhai]] of [[Taizhou, Zhejiang|Taizhou]], [[Zhejiang Province]] on May 3rd of 1920. Xu graduated from the Department of Physics of [[Zhejiang University]] in 1942. Xu was a student of Shu Xingbei (aka [[Hsin Pei Soh]], [[:zh:束星北|束星北]]) and [[Wang Ganchang]] ([[:zh:王淦昌|王淦昌]]). Xu was an [[editing|editor]] of ''Chinese Science Bulletin'' (科学通报), a popular [[science magazine]] in China. Xu was treated unfairly during [[Mao Zedong|Mao]]'s [[Anti-Rightist Movement]] which started in 1957, and he was sent back to his hometown to "[[Laogai]]". After [[Deng Xiaoping|Deng]]'s political reform, Xu reobtained his normal citizenship, and went back to work in [[Beijing]].<ref>http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/22/science/22prof.html?pagewanted=all</ref> Xu was a longtime [[researcher]] at the Institute for the History of Natural Science, [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]] (中国科学院自然科学史研究所). ==Work== Xu's main interests were in the [[history of science]], the [[philosophy of science]] (especially of [[physics]]), and the relations between science and [[human society]]. Xu's ''The Collected Works of Albert Einstein'' (《爱因斯坦文集》) currently is the most comprehensive Chinese translational version of [[Albert Einstein]]'s work.<ref>China.com.cn Book Reviews: [http://www.china.com.cn/international/txt/2008-04/18/content_14976106.htm 爱因斯坦文集：一部对中国人影响超常的科学家著作]</ref> ==Award== Xu received the second [[Andrei Sakharov Prize (APS)|Andrei Sakharov Prize]], from the [[American Physical Society]] (APS) in 2008.<ref>APS: [http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/sakharov.cfm Andrei Sakharov Prize]</ref> ==References== <references/> ==External links== * [[Baidu]].com [[Encyclopedia]] (in Chinese): [http://baike.baidu.com/view/309761.htm Biography of Xu Liangying] * [http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/prizerecipient.cfm?name=Liangying%20Xu&year=2008 2008 Andrei Sakharov Prize Recipient: Liangying Xu (''Chinese Academy of Sciences'')] * [[The New York Times]]: [http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/22/science/22prof.html?_r=2&pagewanted=1&n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/People/O/Overbye,%20Dennis Einstein’s Man in Beijing: A Rebel With a Cause] * APS: [http://www.aps.org/about/pressreleases/041308-xu.cfm APS Honors Chinese Scientist and Human Rights Activist] * China Digital Times: [http://chinadigitaltimes.net/2006/08/einsteins-man-in-beijing-a-rebel-with-a-cause-dennis-overbye/ Einstein’s Man in Beijing: A Rebel With a Cause -
